quireStruct.quireNote: Foliation starts over at 1 Kings (114r becomes 1r, noted hereafter as 1r (bis)) in vol. 1.

In vol. 2, foliation restarts at the Gospels (1r (bis) instead of 144r). For both volumes, we have excluded the tables of contents from the number of folios, as these are not numbered but given only quire letters.

physChar.rubricNote: Chapter titles and numbers appear in all books. Titles added to all non-Guyart books including psalter.Titles and other rubics set apart typographically using space or paragraph markers. No red ink or underlining.
physChar.pageLayoutNote: Handwritten corrections added, apparently based on comparison wih a diiferent (manuscript?) copy, since the added notes supply missing passages. Probably dting to 16th century..

personalization.colophon: A lhonneur et louenge de la benoiste trinite de paradis a este imprimee ceste bible en francois hystoriee Pour Anthoine verard marchant libraire demourant a paris deuant la rue neufue nostre dame a lensiegne sainct iehan leuangeliste Ou au palais au premier pillier deuant la chapelle ou len chante la messe de messeigneurs les presidens.

annotation.name: Somebody
annotation.textReferenced: Paresce fait donner voulente de dormir et ame dissolue aime fain

illustration.keywords: Guyart? reading a manuscript in a library

A monk reads at his desk; Christ appears in the doorway to the right, showing his hand and side wounds from which blood flow. Handwritten note along the right side reads, “Si spectem siccis oculis tua vulnera Christe / Sum +ce sum [small drawing looking like a heart split into three parts] vis aurior jrse(?) tuis.”
Full page woodcut showing God, styled a king in crown and robes, holding a globis cruciger and flanked by angels, creating Eve from sleeping Adam’s side in an enclosed castle garden.

Full page woodcut of original sin. Adam and Eve bear fig leaves, enclosed in a sphere at the base of a tree. Between them stands the Tree of Knowledge around which Satan is coiled, speaking to Eve, who is facing away from Adam and holds an apple; Adam looks toward Eve holding up an apple (from which a bite has been taken).
God, Creation day 1: heaven and earth. He holds clouds in either hand, with a large orb before him.
God, Creation day 2: separation of the waters, creation of firmament
God, Creation day 3: plant life and fruit trees
God, Creation day 4: sun, moon, and stars
God, Creation day 5: birds and fish
God, Creation day 6: animals, Adam, and Eve

Father, Son, and Holy Spirit deliberate about the creation of humanity in a cloud in the upper right corner. Below men and women look up praying. In the middle of the group lies a pile of vegetables and fruit. The gloss explains that prior to original sin, humans were meant to rule over animals and eat only plant life. After original sin, humans had to eat animals and use them for clothing and help with work. They are now lords over neither very large (lions) nor very small (mice) animals.
Adam and Eve on either side of God, under the stars, prior to the Fall.
Adam and Eve escorted out of the gate of Paradise by an angel with a burning sword.
Eve breastfeeds near a fireplace with a spindle dangling from her right hand, while Adam plunges a shovel in the ground.
Abel and Cain making offerings at the altar in upper left, in the lower right, Cain slays Abel in a field
Generations of Cain. Four women, one pours water in a cistern, one attends the one giving birth, the fourth stands in the background with uncovered head looking on.
Noah receives the dove with the olive branch from the top of the ark.
Noah disembarks from the ark.
Noah offers a clean animal on the altar to God, who looks down with a smile from above.
Noah found drunk in the vineyard by his son Cham, brothers Sem and Japeth are in the background.
Building the Tower of Babel.
Ninus prays in front of the statue he has made to honor his father Belus.
Abraham, Sarah, and Lot travel to Canaan.
Melchisedech brings forth bread and wine to bless Abraham for his deliverance of Sodom from its enemies.
Sara tells Abraham that he has wronged her with Hagar.
God gives Abraham his new name, and calls for circumcision. Ishmael stands behind Abraham.
Abraham prays on his knees before the three visiting angels outside his house.
Lot greets an angel at the gates of Sodom.
Destruction of Sodom, Lot’s wife turned into a pillar of salt.
Fire and brimstone rain down on Sodom and Gomorrah.
Abraham and Sarah before King Abilemech.
Sarah and Isaac.
Abraham raises a sword to sacrifice Isaac, but an angel stays it.
Esau gives Jacob his birthright (here represented by a bow) for a bowl of stew.
Jacob tricks Isaac into giving him his blessing.
Jacob’s dream of the ladder with angels ascending and descending.
Laban catches up to fleeing Jacob and they make a convenant.
Jacob wrestles with the angel at the Ford of Jabbok.
Joseph is sold by his brothers.
Joseph in the cistern.
Reuben laments that Joseph is no longer in the cistern.
Potiphar’s wife propositions Joseph.
The cupbearer’s dream.
Pharaoh’s first dream.
The brothers return to Egypt with Benjamin.
Joseph reveals his identity to his brothers.
Jacob blesses Reuben.

Beginning of the book of Exodus. Three panels, left to right: the new Egyptian king does not know Joseph; Moses leads the Israelites; the Israelites cross the Red Sea while Pharaoh and his company are drowned.
Discovery of baby Moses on the banks of the Nile.
After young Moses breaks Pharaoh’s crown, a priest proves the boy’s innocence by offering him a plate of burning coals; he puts one in his mouth and burns his tongue.
Moses sees God in the burning bush. A horned Moses. He is horned in all further illustrations in the book.
Moses speaks to Pharaoh and warns him of plagues.
God speaks to Moses about the plague of frogs.
The children of Israel prepare to sacrifice a lamb, according to God’s instructions for Passover.
Large woodcut. Pharaoh’s army is drowned in the Red Sea while the sky storms above and a pillar burns; the Israelites look on from the wooded bank where they are encamped.
Manna rains down from heaven, while the Israelites gather it in baskets.
Moses strikes a rock with his staff and a river flows from it; the Israelites look on behind him.
God gives Moses the tablets, above, while below, the Israelites gather to request Aaron to make them a god.
Above, God tells Moses that the people are sinning; below, Moses tells the Israelites that they have sinned, pointing to the golden calf, the broken tablets at his feet.

Large three paneled woodcut to introduce Book of Leviticus. From left to right: God speaks to Moses and holds his hands; a woman brings her son before the priest for circumcision; Moses anoints Aaron with oil.

Large three paneled woodcut to introduce Book of Numbers. From left to right: An older man counts a younger man for the census; the sons of Aaron act as priests in the tabernacle; Israelites arrive on the plains of Moab ready to fight, as Moses explains prescriptions for the observance of feasts. Right woodcut is a repeat of illustration 24, Melchisedech thanking Abraham.
Image of God’s instructions to Moses and Aaron concerning the way in which the tribes of Israel are to camp around the tabernacle.
Aaron and Mary beseech Moses to pray to God to heal Mary’s leprosy.
The spies (Caleb and Joshua?) sent to Canaan by Moses bring back a cluster of grapes.

One of the spies shows the Israelites fruits taken from Canaan. Illustration appears to head a new chapter (14), but in fact pertains to the end of chapter 13—a marginal note indicates where chapter 14 actually begins.
Aaron’s rod sprouts overnight, bearing flowers and ripe almonds. There is a dove (?) on the top of the flowering rod.
The murmuring Israelites are plagued by fiery serpents, below; above, Moses erects the brazen serpent by which God will heal them.
An angel of the Lord, sword drawn, stands in the way of Balaam, whose ass is turning away.
Moses instructs the Israelites, per God’s command, to kill anyone who fornicates with Madian women; upper right, a man has stabbed an Israelite and a Madian woman in the act of sex.

Beginning of the book of Deuteronomy. Two panels, left to right: Moses sitting on a chair preaches to the Israelites; in a 16th century church, a priest reads from a Bible to congregation sitting in pews.
Beginning of the book of Joshua. Three panels, left to right: God commissions Joshua to lead the Israelites; the destruction of Canaan; Joshua’s farewell.
The stoning of Achan for his theft.

Beginning of the book of Judges. Three panels, left to right: Deborah and Jael(?); Samson escapes the Philistines in Gaza by tearing off the doors of the city gates and carrying them away; destruction of the tribe of Benjamin.
Ehud murders Egon, the King of Moab, with a sword.
God visits Gideon and promises him success against the Midianites.
Abimelek has his armor-bearer stab him after a woman in a tower drops a millstone on his head.
Jephthah honors his vow to sacrifice the first thing he sees when he returns successful from battle—his daughter.
“Samson the strong.” He runs over top a pile of defeated enemies.
Samson kills a lion with his bare hands.
Samson strikes down a thousand Philistines with the jawbone of a donkey.
Samson escapes the Philistines in Gaza by tearing off the doors of the city gates and carrying them away. Repeat of second woodcut in three-paneled illustration introducing the book of Judges.
The Levite man and his concubine at her parents’ house.

Beginning of the book of 1 Samuel. Three panels, left to right: Samuel gathers the Israelites to denounce false gods; David carries Goliath’s head before a group of onlookers playing instruments; Jonathan warns David about Saul’s plan to kill him. Left panel a repeat of illustration 71.
Hannah dedicates Samuel to the priesthood.
The Philistines capture the ark.
David prepares to slay Goliath with a sword.
Saul raises his spear against David.
Michal helps David escape from Saul by lowering him out her window.
Saul orders his guards to kill the priests who have sided with David.
God tells David to go up to Hebron.
The warring houses of Saul and David face one another.
Joab murders Abner.
Top: Nathan rebukes David. Bottom: David fasts and prays for God to save his child.
Adonias worships Solomon as the rightful king. Repeat of illustration 48 (the new Egyptian king doesn’t recognize Joseph).
Solomon determines the real mother of a baby by proposing the two women split him in half.
The Queen of Sheba visits Solomon to test his knowledge.
Elias prays to God to bring the widow’s son back from the dead.
Elias successfully prays for the fire to be lit under the altar to prove God’s might to worshippers of Baal.
Josaphat and Achab discuss whether or not to go to battle.
A fiery chariot takes Elias to heaven in whirlwind as Eliseus kneels praying.
Eliseus raises a child from the dead.
The coronation of Joas.
The King of Babylon lifts King Joachin of Juda out of prison.

Large three paneled woodcut to introduce Book of Paralipomenon/1Chronicles. From left to right: All of Israel is numbered in the book of kings; David and his champions; David anoints Solomon. Second woodcut is a repeat of 46 (Joseph reveals himself), third woodcut is a repeat of 60 (Moses anoints Aaron).

Large three paneled woodcut to introduce Book of 1 Esdras. From left to right: Led by high priest Jeshua, the captive Israelites return to Jerusalem; Darius is informed that the Israelites are rebuilding the temple; Ezra is informed that some Jews in Jerusalem have taken non-Jewish wives. Third woodcut is a repeat of 83, right panel introducing the book of 1 Kings (Samuel), Jonathan warning David about Saul.
Nehemiah before Artaxerxes. Repeat of left woodcut in illustration 48 introducing the Book of Exodus, and illustration 94, Adonias worshipping Solomon as true king.

Ezra expounds the law of Moses to the people. Repeat of illustration 46, Joseph revealing his identity, and 104, David and his champions, center woodcut introducing the Book of Paralipomenon (1 Chronicles).
Two-panel woodcut introducing the Book of Job. Left: Job and his household feasting together. Right: A devil attacks Job from behind while his wife stands before him explaining why he is suffering.
Tobias and his kin travel to Ninevah. Repeat of illustration 23, Abraham and Sarah traveling to Canaan.

Nebuchadnezzar makes Godolias governor over the Israelites. Repeat of illustrations 71, God commissioning Joshua to lead the Israelites, and 83, Samuel gathering the Israelites to renounce false gods.
Daniel and his wise companions in the palace of the king.
Daniel is shut up in the lion’s den.
Daniel exposes Bel for a fraud and defeats the dragon with balls of hair and fat.
Beginning of the Book of Judith. One large woodcut with two separate scenes. Left: Holofernes and his army attacks a city. Right: Judith holds the severed head of Holofernes from a rampart.
Achior is held captive by the Israelites.
Beginning of the Book of Esther. King Assuerus makes Esther his queen; the King and Esther embrace.
Large single woodcut, ¾ of the page, introducing the Book of Psalms. Left, King David is crowned. Right, David sits at a desk where he has been writing, and inspects his quill.

End of Book One. Repeat of dedication stamp at the beginning. Text surrounding an image of gryffons holding an inscribed heart, angels holding a coat of arms and crown: “Pour provocoverta grant misericorde de tovs pechevrs faire grace et pardon anthoine verad humblement te recorde ce quil ail tient de toi pardon.”
Guyart (?) or a scribe writing at a desk.

Large single woodcut, ¾ of the page, introducing the Book of Proverbs. Left, King Solomon is crowned. Right, Solomon sits at a desk where he has been writing, and inspects his quill. Repeat of illustration 117, beginning of Psalms.

Large single woodcut, ¾ of the page, introducing the Book of Ecclesiastes. Various images. Left: a king (Solomon?) speaks to a young man. Center: a man (Solomon?) reclines on a bed; young knights stand petitioning before him. Upper right: a young woman and a young man stand talking on a balcony.

Three-panel woodcut introducing the Song of Solomon. Left to right: A king and a queen sit together on their thrones; A king places a crown on a kneeling woman’s head; top: a king and a queen stand together, bottom: a man and woman embrace. Right woodcut is a repeat of illustration 116, introduction to the Book of Esther.

Three-panel woodcut introducing the Book of Wisdom. Left to right: A king stands behind a man preparing to behead another man; a group of men and women surround a child; a kneeling man petitions a king. Left panel repeat of illustration 73, destruction of the tribe of Benjamin; center, cf. 45, right, cf. illustrations 48, 94, 106.
Solomon prays to God for wisdom. Repeat of illustration 60, left woodcut, Moses and God.

Three-panel woodcut introducing Ecclesiasticus. Left to right: A kneeling man presents an accounting sheet to a king; center, two men speak to one another; right, a group of men and women surround a child; a young man is presented a king by his father. Left panel, cf. left panel of 104; center, cf. illustrations 83, right panel of 105; right, cf. left panel from 105.
Repeat of illustration 85, the Philistines stealing the ark.
Priest preaching to a congregation. Repeat of right panel introducing Deuteronomy, illustration 70.
Large, ½ page woodcut introducing the Book of Isaiah. Isaiah holds the spheres and elements in one large circle. He wears a an astronomer’s(?) hat, and a blank banner floats above his head.
Isaiah fortelling the stubbornness of the Jews (?). Cf. illustrations 83, 105, 121
Captivity of the Egyptians (?). Cf. illustration 88, Michal lowering David out her window to help him escape.
A priest preaches to a group of people; a young girl prays before the pulpit. “The Lord’s favor to his church.”
Christ (?) surrounded by witnesses. “How the Lord promises mercy to those who return to him.”
The scribes. Cf. illustration 111, Daniel and his companions in the palace of the King of Babylon.
Merodach sends messengers to Ezekiel. Cf. illustrations 104, 121.
A woman giving birth, attended by midwives; the birth of the Virgin.

Three panel introduction to the Book of Jeremiah. Left panel, Benjamin prophesying, center panel, Benjamin talks to God, right panel, Benjamin talks to the king. Left panel, cf. illustrations 46, 104, 107; center panel, cf. 60, 120.
Benjamin cries for his people. Cf. illustration 41, Reuben at the empty cistern.
Benjamin prophesies to a seated group.
The priests raise their swords to kills Jeremiah, but he is protected by King Joakim (in the background).
Jeremiah holding a bill of sale, imprisoned at the house of Sedecias. Cf. illustration 103, Joachim lifted out of prison.
Ishmahel and the nobles slay Godolias. Cf. illustrations 73 and 119.
Destruction of Jerusalem. A weeping fugitive flees across a rampart.
Three panel introduction to the Book of Baruch. Left panel, cf. illustrations 46, 104, 107, 132; center panel, cf. 104, 121, 130; right panel, cf. 60, 104.
Jeremiah’s letter to the captives. Cf. illustrations 103, 136.

The panel introduction to the Book of Ezekiel. Left, the commission of the army; center, Ezekiel speaks to the king; right, prophesy of Christ. Left panel, cf. 71, 83, 110; center, 132; right, 45, 119.
All without a mark on their forehead will be destroyed. Cf. illustrations 105, 121.
God will remember his covenant with Israel (Christ?). Cf. illustrations 45, 119, 141.
Ezekiel prophesies against the nations. Looks like Christ with disciples.
A knight charges into battle. “How our Lord revenged the children of Israel against their enemies.”

Three panel introduction to the Book of Daniel. Left, Nebuchadnezzar sieges Jerusalem; center, Daniel interprets the King’s dreams; right, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in the fiery furnace. Left, cf. 73, 119, 137; center, cf. 104, 121, 130, 139.
Gabriel tells Daniel of the 70 weeks to the coming of Christ.
The Last Judgment and Resurrection.
Two panel introduction to the Book of Hosea. Left: Hosea takes an adultress at God’s command. Right: Hosea prophesies to the Israelites.
Hosea prophesies to a crowd. Cf. illustrations 46, 104, 107, 132, 139.
Introduction to the Book of Amos. A battle scene, the judgment of Israel’s neighbors.
Introduction to the Book of Obadiah. Soldiers besiege a tower, the destruction of Edom.
Introduction to the Book of Jonah. Jonah dives off of a ship into the open mouth of a whale.
Introduction to the Book of Micah. Cf. illustrations 45, 119, 141, 143.
Introduction to the Book of Nahum. God sends his armies against Ninevah. Cf. illustration 91.
Introduction to the Book of Habakkuk. The enemies of God’s people? Cf. illustrations 85, 122.
Introduction to the Book of Zephaniah. Cf. illustration 59.
The rebuilding of the temple.
The prophet admonishes the people.
Introduction to the Book of Malachi. Cf. illustrations 103, 136, 140.
Introduction to the Book of 1 Maccabees. Large woodcut of Alexander routing his enemies.
Introduction to the Book of 2 Maccabees. Dedication of the altar of the new temple. Cf. illustrations 60, 104, 139.

Introduction to the Book of Matthew. ¾ page woodcut of Christ on the cross, with each of the four evangelists and their symbols arranged around him. God is present above, surrounded by a host of angels, while the Holy Spirit (in the form of a dove) hovers between them.
Mary holds Jesus for the magi to present their gifts.
John baptizes Jesus.
The devil tempts Jesus in the desert.
Jesus calls Matthew.

Introduction to the Book of Mark. ¾ page woodcut of Christ on the cross, with each of the four evangelists and their symbols arranged around him. God is present above, surrounded by a host of angels, while the Holy Spirit (in the form of a dove) hovers between them. Cf. illustration 163.
John the Baptist is beheaded.
Christ’s transfiguration.

Introduction to the Book of Luke. ¾ page woodcut of Christ on the cross, with each of the four evangelists and their symbols arranged around him. God is present above, surrounded by a host of angels, while the Holy Spirit (in the form of a dove) hovers between them. Cf. illustrations 163, 168.
John the Baptist preaches to a crowd.
Jesus teaching in the temple. Cf. illustration 134.
Judas betrays Jesus with a kiss.

Introduction to the Book of John. 3/4 page woodcut of Christ on the cross, with each of the four evangelists and their symbols arranged around him. God is present above, surrounded by a host of angels, while the Holy Spirit (in the form of a dove) hovers between them.
Three panel introduction to the Book of Romans. Cf. illustrations: left, 45, 119, 141, 143, 154; center, 46, 104, 107, 132, 139, 150; right, 104, 121, 130, 139, 146.
Introduction to the Book of 1 Corinthians. Cf. illustrations 45, 119, 141, 143, 154, 175.
Introduction to the Book of 2 Corinthians. Cf. illustrations 46, 104, 107, 132, 139, 150, 175.
Introduction to the Book of Galatians. Cf. illustration 83, 105, 121, 125.
Introduction to the Book of Ephesians. Cf. illustrations 85, 122, 156.
Introduction to the Book of Philippians. Cf. illustrations 60, 104, 139, 162.
Introduction to the Book of Thessalonians. Cf. illustrations 134, 173.

Three panel introduction to the Book of Acts. Left: the apostles are sent out; center: Christ’s assumption; right: the apostles are persecuted. Cf. illustrations left, 104, 121, 130, 139, 146, 175; right, 73, 119, 137, 146.
Introduction to Book of James. Picture of Saint James with his staff and shell.
Introduction to the Book of Jude. Picture of Saint Jude preaching. Cf. illustration 172.

1/2 page woodcut introducing to the Book of Revelation. John kneels before an altar upon which stand the twelve apostles. Around him devils crawl and perch on pillars. Two men stand behind him talking to one another.

illustrations.illustrationNote: Illustration descriptions by Courtney Palmbush. Some woodcuts repeat themselves, and some are borrowed from other books printed in Vérard's workship

catalogerClassifications.secundoFolio: Sensuyt la table du premier volume
catalogerClassifications.classificationNotes: Sneddon does not mention this edition specifically, but it must be similar to the 1510 Vérard edition he describes.

prefatoryMatter.otherPreface: Poures pecheurs aueuglez de bien faire qui viuez en ce monde et auez les cuers mondains et molz a mal faire
prefatoryMatter.MasterTableOfContents: Sensuyt la table du premier volume de la grant bible en francois corrigee nouuellement. Et premierement de genese Le prologue. fueillet premier Comment le ciel et la terre furent creez et tous les autres elemens chapitre. i. f ii…
prefatoryMatter.prefatoryNote: Guyart's prologue has been replaced by Verard’s. Tables of contents for both volumes appear in the first volume. Second volume table is repeated in the second volume as well.

prefatoryMatter.otherPreface: Pour inciter tous bons chrestiens a paruenir au chemin de la gloire eternelle il est requis veoir et ouir la parolle de nostre seigneur iesuchist
prefatoryMatter.MasterTableOfContents: Cy commence la table du second volume de la grant bible translateee de latin en francois Et de nouueau corrigee sur le latin. Et premierement des paraboles de salomon.

title.incipit: Au commencement crea Dieu le ciel et la terre
Au commencement fut le filz.
Princeps mundi eiicietur foras.
Cy sont les noms des filz disrael qui entrerent en egypte auec iacob
Lhistoire de exode nest pas aultre de lhistoire devant de genesis ainsi est la mesme histoire continuee dicelluy
Histoire sur ceste partie devant dicte en exode. Long temps apres la mort de ioseph et la mort pharaoh soubz qui Joseph fut
title.bookNote: Page header reads “De genese” on leaf 47.

title.incipit: Au commencement de leuitique met le maistre en histoires une diuision moult prouffitable pour entendre leuitique et dit ainsi ce liure leuitique est la tierce histoire quod moyse escript
Nostre seigneur parla a moyse du tabernacle de telmoignage et luy dist.
Or laissons a tant le texte et allons a la lettre du maistre en histoires qui parle sur le texte de leuitique en ceste maniere Et ainsi comanda nostre seigneur a moyse en leuitique.
Cest a dire lavoit.
title.bookNote: Page headers read “De leuitique” starting at 61, but Leviticus does not actually begin until 63. The prologue contains several Texte and Glose entries. The first chapter of Leviticus begins on leaf 63v, under the heading, “Des sacrifices selon lhistoire.” Beneath this heading is written in different, lighter script, “Chap. premier, selon le bible en latin”

title.incipit: La quarte histoire de ce liure est appellee le liure des nombres ou le nombre et cest bien droit car en ce liure sont quatre choses comptees.
Nostre seigneur parla a moyse au desert de Sinay
Notez cy que moyse trespassa cy autres choses qui furent faictes au premier moys du second an de leur yssue degipte
title.bookNote: “Cha. 1.” is written in the left margin of 70v, where the Texte begins

title.incipit: La quinte histoire et derniere que moyse escript en grec est appellee deuteronome
Au xle. an de lissue des filz disrael degipte au. ixe. moys le premier iour du moys sicomme dit le maistre en histoires.
Au desert encontre la rouge mer entre pharan et chophol et balaan et asseroth et la ou il ya moult dor
Cest a dire deca iourdain.
title.bookNote: “Cha. primier” is written above the beginning of the histoire. The prologue includes several Texte and Glose, the histoire has a Glose.

title.incipit: Au commencement du livre de iosue devons nous scavoir qui lest appellee le livre iosue pource que iosue le fist.
Nostre seigneur parla a Iosue le filz nim.
Voire apres la mort de moyse quant le people eut laisse le plorer.
Le livre des iuges en hebrieu est apelle Sophin.
Apres la mort iosue prindrest conseil a nostre seigneur les filz disrael par phinees le preste.
Et ie iray auec toy et ton sort
title.bookNote: Ending rubric: Cy fine le liure des iuges / et de ruth

title.incipit: Ce liure des roys est diuise en quatre liures selon les latins.
Ung home de ramathayn sophim du mout effraym nofme helyn qui fut filz tan qui fut filz Suph et fut de helcas na de la terre dessrata
En sainct Mathieu et en sainct luc au chaptire comment iesus fut mis au monument
title.bookNote: Page numbers start again at 1

title.incipit: Apres la mort de saul et apres ce que dauid venoit doccire ceulx damalech ou il aoura nostre seigneur.

Cy diest les hebrieux que celluy qui apportatelles nouuellles a dauid fut filz de obeth ydumee et qui son pere aincois quil soccist ainsi saul luy donna les noblesses du roy comme sa couronne et son armeure
Cy commence selon nous le tiers liure des roys et selons les hebrieux le second
Le roy dauid estoit fort enuieilly et auoit grant aage ne il ne se pouoit eschauffer pour draps dont on le couurist.
Cest a dire de la cite de surie.
Ochosiele le filz achab commenca a regner en samarie sur ysrael
Dont on lit au tiers liure des roys au chapitre de iheroboam.
Adam/seth/enos/caynam/malalehel/iares/enoch/mathusale/lameth/noe
Salomon le filz de Dauid fut conforte en son regne et dieu estoit auecques luy
Au premier an de Cyrus roy de perse que la parole de nostre seigneur me fust acomplie et dicte par la bouche de hieremie
Les paroles Neemie le filz delchie.
title.bookNote: Headings “Le second liure De esdras” and “Neemye” alternate with “Le premier liure de Esdras” several leaves before the book actually starts.

title.incipit: Iosye fist pasques en hierusalem a nostre Seigneur: et sacrifia pasques au quatorziesme iour du premier Moys establissans les prestres par leurs offices des iours vestuz de stolles au temple de nostre seigneur.
Ung homme estoit en la terre de hus qui avoit nom iob et celluy homme estoit iuste et droicturier et craignoit dieu et foy departant de mal.
title.bookNote: Following the introduction of the book of Job “Cy apres ensuyt le livre de Job,” on 97v, there is a note, which I cannot make out entirely.

title.incipit: Thobie de la lignee et cite de neptalin qui est es plus haultes parties de galilee dessus naason apres la voye qui maine en occident allans en la senestre partie de la cite de sephet.

Nous devons cy scavoir que lhystoire de thobie commenca quant salmanasar le roy de Ninive mena en chetiuoison les dix lignees comme on trouue au quart liure des roys au chapitre de la chetiuoison des dix lignees
Or allons auant et retournois a lhistoire de la chetiuoison de iherusalem dont nous auons parle en la fin du quart liure des roys

Quant nabuchodonosor roy de babiloine eut fait godolie souuerain sur les iuifz qui estoient demourez es citez de iudee et renuoiez de la chetiuoison ou leurs freres estoient menez en Babiloine comme nous lysons en la fin du quart liure de roys.
title.bookNote: End of Tobit, intro: “Cy fine le liure de thobie Et commencent les liures de iheremie/ezechie/daniel et susanne.”

title.incipit: Cest histoire de iudich translata en latin iherosme a la priere de tressaictes vierges eustochius et paule de caldee.
Quant cyrus fut mort arphasat le roy des mediens auoit soubzmis plusieurs gens a son empire.
Le maistre dit en histoire que nabuchodonosor fut cambises le filz cyrus.
title.bookNote: Within this book is an introduction and subset of chapters “Des Sept Saiges”

title.incipit: Le liure hester translata sainct hierosme a la priere de paule et eustochii de hebrieu en latin.
Au temps que le roy assuerus regna des indes iusques en ethiope sur. c. et. xxvii prouinces la cite de suse fut le chief de son regne.

Le maistre dit en histoires dalexandre que les colombes estoient dargent du lieu ou il estoit et le ciel aussi comment le firmament fut fait de diuerses couleurs ordonnees en maniere destoilles et des signes.
Beatus vir qui non abiit.
title.bookNote: End of book 1.

title.incipit: Les paraboles Salomon filz de dauid roy de hierusalem pour scauoir sapience Et pour entendre les parolles de prudence et a receuoir enseignement de doctrine et iustice
Les parolles de ecclesiastes filz de dauid roy de hierusalem / vanite des vanitez dist ecclesiastes la vanite des vanitez et toutes choses sont vanitez.
title.bookNote: Recto and verso of leaf 12 contain part of ch. 23, ch. 24, and part of ch. 25 of Matthew. The leaf heading also reads “Sainct mathieu” recto, and “Les evangilles” verso. The book then returns to Ecclesiastes on leaf 13.

title.incipit: Les cantiques de salomon sont exposees diuersement par diuers docteurs
Celle me baise dung baiser de sa bouche
title.bookNote: Leaf heading is “Lecclesiasticque” on 16v.

title.incipit: Aymez iustice vous qui iugez la terre et sentez de nostre seigneur en bonte et pareillement le querez en simplesse de cueur
Toute sapience est de dieu qui est nostre seigneur et fut en tous temps auec luy et sera pardurablement.
La prophetie ysaie le filz amos que il vit dessus le peuple de iuda et de hierusalem au temps de ozie et au temps ioachin et au temps de achas et au temps de ezechiel qui furent roys de iuda.

Les parolles de Jheremie prophete filz helchie des prestres qui furent en anathot en la terre beniamin que la parole de nostre seigneur fut faicte a luy au temps dysaie filz Amos roy de Juda au treiziesme an de son royaulme.
title.bookNote: Leaf heading is “ysaye” on 58v. “Les lamentacions de iheremie le prophete” begin on leaf 78v: “Aleth. Comment fiet la cite seule qui estoit plaine de people.”

title.incipit: Le liure qui Baruth est appellee nest pas les hebrieux en leur canon ainsi est tant seullement en vulgal edicion
Ce sont les parolles que escript baruch filz nerie le filz maasie le filz sedechie.
Il aduint ou. xiiie. an ou quint iour du meillieu des chetifz decoste le siege chobar les cieulx ouurirent et ie viz vision de dieu ou quint iour du moys.

Au tiers an du royaulme ioachim roy de iuda nabuchodonosor roy de babiloine vint en hierusalem et lassiegist et nostre seigneur bailla en sa main ioachim roy de iuda et partie des vaisseaulx de la maison nostre seigneur
La parolle de nostre seigneur qui fut faicte a osee filz beery au temps ioatham / acham et ezechie de iuda et au temps iheroboam filz ioas roy disrael.
title.bookNote: Page numbering is off—there are two 109s (CVIX, and CVIIII)

title.incipit: La parolle de nostre seigneur faicte a Joel filz statuel. Vous viellars oyez cecy.
Les parolles amos qui fut es pastorals de thecue que il vit sur ysrael ou temps de Ozie roy de iuda et ou temps de hieroboam filz Joyas roy disrael deuant deux ans que la terre tremblast et dist.
LAvision abdie ce dist nostre seigneur a edon nous auons ouy de nostre seigneur et il enuoya messages aux gens Leuons nous fus et allons contre luy en bataille.
La parolle de nostre seigneur fut faicte a ionas filz emath disant. Lieue toy va en niniue grant cite et presche illec Car sa malice est montee contre moy.
La parolle’de nostre seigneur qui fut faicte a michee et demonstree ou temps de ioachin de achas et ezechie roy de iuda quil vit sur samarie et sur hierusalem.

Les faitz de niniue le liure des visions naum delchese. Nostre seigneur est vengeant et grant ire a nostre seigneur est pacient et grant mercy et nettoye Et ne fait pas iniquite les voyes de nostre seigneur sont on tempeste et en estourbillon.
Les fais que abacuth le prophete dit. Sire pourquoy crieray ie et vous ne me orrez pas. Pourquoy crierary ie souffrant force et vous ne me sauuerez pas.
La parolle de nostre seigneur fut faicte a sophonie filz chusy filz godelie Amasie filz ezechie ou temps iosue filz amon roy de iuda.

Au second an du regne daire qui estoit roy de perse au septiesme moys. La parolle de nostre seigneur fut faicte a aggee le prophete a zorobabel filz salathiel duc de iuda et de ihesus filz Josedech qui estoit prince des prestres disant ce dist nostre seigneur qui est sire des ostz de son sainct mont.

Au huytiesme moys au second an daire la parolle de nostre seigneur fut faicte a zacharie filz abdo le prophete disant. Nostre seigneur est courrouce contre voz peres en son yre et tu leur diras ce dist nostre seigneur qui est seigneur des ostz.
Les fais des parolles de nostre seigneur aisrael en la main de malachiel le prophete Je vous ay aymez ce dist nostre seigneur et vous dictes.

Apres ce que alexander filz du roy philippe de macedoine qui yffit de la terre cethim et fut le premier roy qui regna en grece et quil eut vaincu daire le roy de perse et de mede advent quil fist plusieurs batailles et print toutes les garnisons et occist les roys de la terre et passa de cy a la fin de toute la terre et print les despouilles de maintes gens et toute terre trembla devant luy
Et firent escole de payens par toute la terre de hierusalem.
Les juifz qui sont en hierusalem en la region de iudee mandent aux juifz leurs freres qui sont en egypte salut et bonne paix
title.bookNote: Leaf headings read “le premiere liure” up to 138v.

title.incipit: Le liure de la generation Jesuchrist filz de david filz abraham.
title.bookNote: Leaf numbers start again at 1. Leaf 12r and v is from Ecclesiastes.

title.incipit: Le commencement de leuangile iesuchrist filz de dieu sicomme il est escript en esaye le prophete. Je enuoyeray mon ange cest a dire mon messagie.
title.bookNote: “deux fois” is underlined on 24v (the cock crows two times and Peter cries)

title.incipit: Pource que plusieurs se sont efforcez de racompter et ordonner les racomptemens que sont acomplis en nous
Au temps de herode roy de iudee ung prestre fut lequel auoit a nom zacharie et administroit en la partie de abye Et sa femme estoit extraicte et nee des filles de aaron et auoit nom elizabeht.
La parolle estoit au commencement et celle parolle estoit enuers dieu cest la congnoissance de dieu le pere et dieu estoit parolle cest dieu le filz.
Les rommains sont des parties dytalie. Jceulx furent deceuz des faulx prophetes et furent menez en la loy des prophetes ou nom de nostre seigneur.

Pol seruiteur de iesuchrist appelle apostre departy en leuangile de dieu de son filz quil auoit promis deuant par les prophetes et sainctes escriptures qui fut ne de la semence de dauid selon la chair qui fut deuant enuoye comme filz de dieu en vertu selon le sainct esperit de la resurrection des mors de iesuchrist nostre seigneur par lequel nous auons receu grace la dignite destre nomme apostre a obeyr a la foy et a toutes gens pour son nom esquelz vous estes appellez de iesuchrist nostre seigneur a tous ceulx qui sont a romme appellez sainctz.

Pol appelle apostre par la voulente de iesucrist et sostenes frere de saincte eglise qui est en corinthe aux sainctifiez en Jesuchrist ou baptesme de iesuchrist appellez sainctz a tous ceulx qui sont reclamans le nom de nostre seigneur iesuchrist en tous leurs lieux et en tous les nostres.
Pol apostre de iesucrist par la voulente de dieu et thimothee frere de leglise de dieu qui est en corinthe a tous les sainctz qui sont en toute achaye.

Pol apostre nom pas des homes ne par homme mais par iesuchrist dieu le pere qui le suscita de mort et tous les freres qui sont auec moy auec les eglises de galathe vous ayez grace de dieu nostre pere et nostre seigueur iesuchrist qui donna soymesmes pour noz pechez quil nous deliurast de ce siècle mauuais selon la voulente de dieu et de nostre pere qui ayt honneur et gloire sans fin.
Pol apostre de iesuchrist par la voulente de dieu. A tous les sainctz qui sont en ephese et aux feaulx en iesuchrist grace soit a vous de dieu nostre pere et de nostre seigneur iesuchrist.
title.bookNote: Book mistakenly introduced as “lepistree de sainct pol aux corinthiens.” Chapter heading is correct: “Comment lapostre met la diuine predestinacion daucuns et raconpte aucuns diuins benefices fais aux apostres et aux ephesiens.”

title.incipit: Pol et thimothee serfz de iesuchrist qui sont en philippense auec les euesques et les diacres vouz ayez grace de dieu et de nostre seigneur iesuchrist. Je rens graces a mon dieu tousiours en toute rememberance de vous en toutes mes oraisons pour vous auec ioye faisant priere de vostre communication en leuangile de christ du premier iour iusques maintenant moy confidant que dieu qui a commence en vous bonne oeuure la parface iusques en la fin comme cest droit que ie sente pourtous vous pource que ie vous ay en cueur et en mes liens en deffendment et en confermement de leuangile estre compaignons tous de ma ioye.

Pol apostre de iesuchrist par la vouente de dieu thimothee frere et ceulx qui sont en colose et sont sainctz et aux feaulx freres en Jesuchrist. Ayez paix et grace de dieu nostre pere et de nostre seigneur iesuchrist.

Pol et siluan et thimothee a leglise de thessalonie en dieu nostre pere et en nostre seigneur Jesuchrist soit auec vous grace et paix. Nous rendons graces a dieu pour vous nous faisons tousiours rememberance de vous en noz oraisons sans entre laisser.

Pol et Siluans et Thimothee ceulx de thessalone qui sont en nostre dieu nostre pere et nostre seigneur iesuchrist. Freres nous deuons graces render tousiours a dieu pour vous comme digne chose est pource que vostre foy croist de iour en iour et chascun de vous habonde enuers lautre si que nous auons gloire en vous en leglise de dieu pour voustre pacience et pour vostre foy et en toutes voz persecutions et voz tribulations que bous soustenez ensemble du droicturier droit de dieu a son iugement que vous foyez dignes de receuoir le royaume de dieu pour lequel vous souffrez

Paul apostre selon le commandement de nostre seigneur et de iesuchrist nostre esperance a thimothee son amy et filz En foy/grace et misericorde et paix de dieu le pere et de iesuchrist nostre seigneur sicomme ie te priay que tu venisse en ephese quant iestoye en macedoine que tu denonceasses a aucuns que ilz nenseignassent autrement ne entendissent a fables ne aux genealogies non determines qui donnent plus questions que ediffiemens de dieu et soit en foy et en charite du pur cueur et de bonne conscience et de foy qui ne soit pas saincte.

Paul apostre de iesuchrist par la voulente de dieu selong promesse de vie qui est en iesuchrist a thimothee son tres chier filz grace et misericorde et paix de dieu mon pere et de iesuchrist nostre seigneur.
title.bookNote: Page number wrong: 77 is missing an x, so it looks like it’s 67.

title.incipit: Pol serf de dieu apostre de iesuchrist selon la foy des amys de dieu et la congnoissance de verite qui est selon pitie en esperance de vie pardurable que dieu qui ne meurt a promis deuant tous les temps du siecle.

Pol lie en lamour de iesuchrist et thimotee frere philemon nostre amy et nostre aydeur et apie nostre treschiere seur et a archippe nostre amy et a leglise qui est en ta maison vous ayez graces et paix de dieu nostre pere et de nostre seigneur iesuchrist.

Dieu parlant iadis a noz peres parles pphetes (sic) en maintes manieres et en maintes formes. Au dernier en ce temps a il parle a nous par son filz quil a estably hoir de toutes choses et par lequel il fist en ce monde.

O Toy Theophile iay premierement parle de toutes les choses que iesus commenca a faire et a enseigner iusques au iour quil commanda par le saincte esperit a ses apostres que il esleut et monter au ciel.

Iaques seruant de nostre seigneur iesuchrist mande salut aux douze lignees qui sont esparses. Mes freres cuydez vous auoir toute ioye quant vous cherrez en temptation sachans que lapprobation de vostre foy est prouuee par pacience.

Pierre apostre de iesuchrist aux gens estranges de ponte de galathie/capadoce/de bythinie et dasie selon la science de dieu le pere au sainctifiement desperit en obedience et arrousement du sang de Jesuchrist/grace et paix vous soit multipliee.
Symon pierre seruiteur de nostre seigneur Jesuchrih a ceulx qui ont receu foy auec nous en la iustice de nostre seigneur iesuchrist.

Nous vous annoncons et tesmoignons des le commencement ce que nous auons ouy et veu a nos yeulx et ce que noz mains ont traicte de parolle de vie qui estoit auecques le pere et nous lauons veu et le tesmoignons et vous annoncons vie qui vous est donnee.

Le vieillart a son seigneur et a ses enfans que ie ayme en verite et ie nayme pas tout seul/ mais tous ceulx qui ont aymee et congneue verite qui demeure en vous/ et fera auecques vous Grace/ misericorde et paix soit auecques vous de dieu le pere et de iesuchrist filz du pere en charite et en verite.

Le vieillart a mon amy gay que iayme en verite De toy treschier frere ie fais oraisons en toutes choses que tu entres en prosperitez et vailles sicomme ton ame est en bon couraige et en bon estat ie me fuis moult esiouy aux freres qui sont venus a moy et ont porte tesmoing a ta verite.
Iudas seruiteur de iesuchrist frere de iaques a ceulx qui sont ses amys en dieu le pere et qui sont gardez et appellez de iesus paix et misericorde et charite en vous soit remplie.

Lapocalipse de iesuchrist que dieu lui donna a sainct iehan pour faire scauoir aux seruiteurs quil commanda a ester tost fait et le signifia annoncant par son ange a Jehan son seruant qui porta tesmoing a la parolle de dieu et a Jesuchrist de tout ce que il vit.

biblioEntry.bookOrJournalTitle: La Bible française au moyen âge: étude sur les plus anciennes versions de la Bible écrites en prose de langue d'oïl.

biblioEntry.articleTitle: Les manuscrits de la Bible historiale.
biblioEntry.bookOrJournalTitle: L'Atelier du Centre de recherches historiques, Revue électronique de la CRH.

biblioEntry.articleTitle: Les éditions de la Bible historiale.

biblioEntry.bookOrJournalTitle: A Critical Edition of the Four Gospels in the Thirteenth-Century Old French Translation of the Bible.
biblioEntry.publicationInfo: Thesis presented for the degree of D. Phil., Oxford Un4ersity, 1978.
